title: Resources and Support for Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC)

content: When you’re diagnosed with primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) you may have a lot of questions. While there is no cure, understanding the condition and creating a support system that you can lean on are key to helping you feel in control and thrive as you live with PBC.

sections.heading: Start With Your Care Team
content: You’ll probably have a lot of questions about your diagnosis. Your care team can help you understand the disease process and what it will mean for you going forward. Having a good relationship with the members of your care team is important in making sure you’re comfortable having them manage your care. It can be helpful for both you and your doctors for you to take notes during appointments and come with questions ready to ask. It also allows you more control over your care.

sections.heading: Online Sources
content: The internet can be a good source of information about PBC, but not all sources are created equal. It may take some careful searching to find which online sources offer up-to-date and reliable information.

content_blocks.text: The internet can be a good source of information about PBC, but not all sources are created equal. It may take some careful searching to find which online sources offer up-to-date and reliable information.

content: When you’re looking for information online, search for websites from federal government agencies such as the CDC or the National Institutes of Health. Those run by hospitals and medical institutions will also generally have reliable, updated information. Large professional organizations and patient advocacy groups are another good place to look when you’re looking for answers to your questions. The American Liver Foundation , PBC Advocate , and PBCers Organization are just some of the organizations that provide the latest information, as well as links to other resources and support groups. To get an idea about whether a site you’re looking at is one you should trust, ask yourself a few questions as you read: Is this site trying to sell a product or service, or is it sponsored by a for-profit entity? Does this site promote the ideas of any particular person or group? Has the information been vetted by a medical professional or backed up by studies? Can I find information about the site owners or the medical reviewers? Does the site offer a balanced viewpoint?

sections.heading: Get Involved With the PBC Community
content: Support groups are a great way to get to know others in the PBC community. They’re an easy and free way to learn more about the condition, ask questions, and to talk to others that share your experience. If you want to get more involved, they often have information about PBC-related events or ways to advocate for the community. Many websites for PBC organizations have information about online groups, local in-person groups, and public meetings. Facebook is another good place to look for online meetups.

sections.heading: How to Involve Family and Friends in Your Diagnosis
content: Whether to involve friends and family in your diagnosis and treatment is up to you. You decide whether you want to share your diagnosis with anyone and how much to share if you do. If you do include friends or family, it can be very helpful for both you and them. It gives you some control and lets your loved ones know how best to support you. With PBC, you may feel tired much of the time. One way you can involve your loved ones in your care is to allow them to let them take on tasks for you, such as making a healthy dinner or running errands. They can also go with you to your appointments or simply drive you and wait in the lobby. There may be times you just want them to watch TV with you. Talk it over and let them know what you need most.

sections.heading: How You Can Support Someone With PBC
content: Learning how best to support your loved one as they manage PBC may take practice and patience with yourself. Some good ways to support your loved one include: Offering to help them with chores or tasks when they are tired. Ask them what would be most helpful. Going with them to doctor visits. You can take notes, make sure your loved one asks all their questions (and gets answers), or just offer moral support. Suggesting things to do that involve getting some exercise, such as going for a walk or to a yoga class. Listening to their concerns and frustrations. Be aware that everyone deals with stress differently. It’s easy to feel overwhelmed when you or a loved one gets a diagnosis of PBC. Finding the right sources of information and support can help you get back a sense of control as you manage your symptoms and learn the best way for you to live with the condition.
